data.title: Hike the Upper Falls Trail
data.accessibilityInformation: This trail is not accessible for wheelchaits or strollers.
data.longDescription: The Falls Trail starts at the end of the Backpacker's Parking Lot near the visitor center. The trail descends 400 vertical feet in its 1.5 mile length to the Upper Falls. A beautiful trail in any season, this trail is not cleared of snow in the winter and can be extremely icy. There are steep dropoffs along the trail and plank bridges across the creek. Keep children close at all times and watch for wildlife. Take plenty of water.

data.title: Hike the Tsankawi Loop Trail
data.shortDescription: Learn everything you need to know about hiking the Tsankawi Loop Trail.

images.altText: A vast view of the Tsankawi area of Bandelier.
images.title: Tsankawi Trail
images.caption: The views go on for miles at Tsankawi.

data.seasonDescription: The trail is open all year, however, can be icy in the the winter months.
data.accessibilityInformation: The Tsankawi trail contains a series of ladders, narrow passages, drop-offs, and elevation gain/loss. Because of these obstacles, the trail may not be accessible to service animals and people with physical impairments.
data.feeDescription: Entrance fee applies. An automatic fee collection machine is available at the trailhead. Visitors are required to display their entry pass on the dashboards of their vehicles.
data.longDescription: The Tsankawi section of Bandelier National Monument is located on State Highway 4 twelve miles from the main section of the park. At Tsankawi you take a 1.5 mile walk along a mesa, viewing cavates, petroglyphs and the Ancestral Pueblo village of Tsankawi. Ladders are a required part of this trail. The trail is very exposed to the elements and should not be taken during localized thunderstorms. Cold, snowy weather can make the trail slippery so extra care should be taken when visiting in winter.

data.title: Become a Bandelier Junior Ranger
data.shortDescription: Information on our junior ranger program at Bandelier

images.altText: Junior Ranger logo with ranger flat hat, words read Explore, Learn, Protect
images.title: Jr. Ranger Logo
images.caption: Junior Ranger logo with flat hat

data.accessibilityInformation: Junior Ranger booklets are available to people of any age or gender. Service animals are allowed on trails. We would be happy to accomodate any junior ranger with disabilities.
data.activityDescription: A short workbook filled with activities for all ages.
data.longDescription:
To participate in this on-site program, the prospective Junior Ranger picks up a workbook at the Visitor Center and fills in the questions while visiting the park. Upon returning to the Visitor Center, a ranger will go over the work with the candidate. Successful candidates receive a Bandelier Junior Ranger wooden badge and our hearty congratulations.
 

Pick up a free ranger booklet at the visitor center when you visit.

If you complete these booklets, you will receive the wooden badge.

Be sure to stop by the visitor center and pick up your supplies before starting your junior ranger adventure.

data.title: Hike the Main Pueblo Loop Trail
data.shortDescription: Summary, things to see, and maps of the famous Pueblo Loop Trail in Bandelier National Monument.

images.altText: remnants of a stone village in the bottom of a canyon with steep rocky tan cliffs and blue sky
images.title: Leaving Tyuonyi Village
images.caption: Leaving Tyuonyi Village

data.accessibilityInformation: Some sections of the Pueblo Loop Trail are flat and on paved surfaces. Although not entirely accessible to wheelchairs and strollers, many visitors enjoy this trail with these devises. The trail includes ladders, narrow spaces, and steps up and down. Ladders to the cavates are optional to hikers.
data.longDescription:
The Pueblo Loop Trail is a 1.4 mile loop trail through archeological sites. Most visitors spend an hour on this trail. Ladders along the trail allow visitors to climb into cavates (small human-carved alcoves). The Pueblo Loop Trail takes you past the Big Kiva, Tyuonyi, Talus House, and Long House.

Pick up a $2 trail guide at the Park Store to learn more about the sites along the trail through descriptions of 21 numbered stops.

The first section of this trail is flatter and may be travelled by wheelchairs and strollers; however, some areas exceed accessibility standards and some areas contain stairs/dropoffs. In winter, this is the only trail on which the snow is removed.

data.title: Hike the Frijoles Canyon & Rim Trail
data.shortDescription: Get details about hiking the Frijoles Loop trail.

images.altText: Frijoles Canyon from the rim section of the Frijoles Loop Trail.
images.title: Frijoles Canyon
images.caption: Frijoles Canyon from the rim section of the Frijoles Loop Trail.

data.accessibilityInformation: This trail is considered strenuous with significant elevation gain. Service animals can access the trail. This hike is only recommended for people in good physical health. It may take responders several hours to arrive on scene if a medical emergency should occur on this trail.
data.longDescription:
The Frijoles canyon trail is an 8 mile one way hike from Ponderosa campground to the Visitor Center. From Ponderosa campground the trail goes into the canyon and turns left along the creek and towards the Visitor Center. Take the time to enjoy the incredible rock formations and relax in the peace and quiet. Be prepared to get your feet wet as there are no bridges, but shallow water.

The Frijoles Rim trail is located on the mesa above Frijoles canyon. From Cottonwood picnic area by the Visitor center, take the Long trail to the Frijoles Rim trail. It connects to the Frijoles canyon trail at the upper crossing of Frijoles creek and allows you to turn this into about a 13 mile loop. This trail gives you expansive views of a good portion of Northern New Mexico and several mountain ranges.

Please note: Ask a ranger at the Visitor Center if you have questions about this trail or condtions.

data.title: Hike the Frey Trail
data.shortDescription: Learn about the Frey trail, including roundtrip mileage, time, and what you will see.

images.title: View from Frey Trail
images.caption: The view from the Frey Trail.

data.accessibilityInformation: The Frey Trial is well developed but is steep and mostly uphill. It may be difficult for strollers, people who are not in good physical shape, and is not accessible to wheelchairs. The Frey Trail is especially difficult in the summer months when temperatures are high. We recommend at least on liter of water per hiker.
data.longDescription:
Before the construction of the entrance road in the late 1930's, the Frey Trail ( 1.5 miles one way) was the main route to enter and exit Frijoles Canyon. The trail begins at Juniper Campground and makes its way to the edge of the canyon where it switchbacks down to the canyon (>550' elevation change). The trail provides excellent views of Tyuonyi. Hiking up is a difficult trail at any time, it can be hot in summer as there is little shelter from the sun along the trail. Be sure and always carry plenty of water.

Hiking down is now a wonderful walk with amazing views. Just be sure to bring water. Also during summer (mid May to mid October) hike down the Frey Trail and take the shuttle bus back up to the trailhead. Check at the visitor center for current conditions of the shuttle bus.

data.title: Cerro Grande Trail
data.shortDescription: Trail description, including roundtrip mileage and what to expect along the way.

images.title: Cerro Grande Trail
images.caption: Solitude is plenty on the Cerro Grande Trail.

data.accessibilityInformation: This trail is considered strenuous because of the elevation gain (1200 ft). It is only recommended for those in good physical shape. The Cerro Grande Trail is not wheelchair accessible but is accessible to service animals.
data.longDescription: The Cerro Grande Route goes up to the highest point in the park, Cerro Grande Peak (10,199 ft). The preferred route is marked by yellow diamonds and is 2.3 miles each way (4.6 round trip). There is an elevation gain of approximately 1200 feet from trailhead to summit. The views from the top are quite spectacular. Snow and ice may be present longer than at lower elevations. In late summer, thunderstorms can pose a serious threat. Before hiking be sure you are prepared with adequate gear and clothing.

data.title: Cross-Country Ski the Blue & Orange Trails
data.shortDescription: Cross-country skiing and other winter recreational activities are available at Bandelier National Monument.

images.altText: Man cross-country skis on a snowy mesa.
images.title: Cross-Country Skiing at Bandelier
images.caption: Man cross-country skis on a snowy mesa top.

data.accessibilityInformation: Cross-country ski trails are not groomed or maintained.
data.longDescription:
Opportunities to cross-country ski, snowshoe, and hike may be found in the Upper Frijoles area of the monument located off of Highway 4, near Forest Service Road 289 (Dome Road). There are four trails - the Cerro Grande Trail, the Alamo Boundary Trail, and the two Upper Frijoles loop trails (one is 2.4 miles round-trip while the other is 5 miles round-trip). Trails are open during daylight hours only. Pets are not permitted. Please pack out all trash. Snowshoe users and hikers are asked to stay to the side of the ski trail.

Seasonal Conditions
Snow volume varies from year to year so call the visitor center (505-672-3861 x 0 or 1800) for current conditions. The ski and snowshoe season usually lasts from mid-November to mid-March. The trails are open all year to hiking.

data.title: Alamo Boundary Trail
data.shortDescription: Learn more about the Alamo Boundary Trail, including roundtrip mileage and where to start the hike.

images.altText: Claret Cup Cactus blooming with bright red flowers.
images.title: Claret Cup Cactus
images.caption: Claret Cup Cactus blooms near the Alamo Boundary Trail.

data.accessibilityInformation: The Alamo Boundary Trail is considered easy and is accessible to service animals.
data.longDescription:
Alamo Boundary Trail is a relatively easy hike from FS 289 to the boundary between the monument and the Valles Caldera National Preserve. The trail is only 1.3 miles each way but it also connects with the Coyote Call Trail on the Valles Caldera. Elevation change on the Alamo Boundary Trail is only 400'. This a trail is a great place for solitude.
The road to access this trail is closed during winter.

data.title: Hiking in Bandelier
data.shortDescription: Hiking in Bandelier? Find trail recommendations, download maps, and explore the sites in Bandelier National Monument.

images.title: Tyuonyi from the Frey Trail
images.caption: Tyuonyi Pueblo as seen from above.

data.accessibilityInformation:
Most of the park's backcountry trails are rugged and strenuous to hike. Expect significant elevation gain & loss, uneven terrain, and moderate route-finding on any of the backcountry trails. 
None of the park trails meet ADA accessibility standards but the Main Loop Trail (Pueblo Loop Trail) is an improved surface trail, it is NOT ADA accessible due to some steep grades, pinch points, lack of railings etc.

Guides to the Main Loop Trail are available in large print, Braille, Spanish, French, Japanese, German, and Russian.

Map showing stairs and steep grades on the Main (Pueblo) Loop trail as of 07/11/20
data.petsDescription: Pets are not permitted on hiking trails at Bandelier National Monument: Pets - Bandelier National Monument (U.S. National Park Service) (nps.gov)
data.longDescription:
Bandelier National Monument has over 70 miles of trail within its boundaries. The most popular of these trails are the Main (Pueblo) Loop Trail and Alcove House Trail which are accessed from the visitor center in Frijoles Canyon. These trails take you to many Ancestral Pueblo sites.

The Falls Trail is another trail that is very popular. It takes you to a beautiful waterfall. Flooding destroyed the trail leaving no access to the Rio Grande from Frijoles Canyon. There are no archeological sites on this trail.

data.title: Bandelier Wildlife Viewing
data.shortDescription: Wildlife is always in the park but not always easy to see. Keep your eyes open as you hike the trails and be amazed at what you may find.

images.altText: a large gray squirrel with a white belly and big ears with tassels
images.title: Abert's Squirrel
images.caption: An Abert's Squirrel has big ears with tassels.

data.accessibilityInformation: Some of the trails are accessible. Some types of wildlife can be seen very close to the park visitor center and on the Main Pueblo Loop Trail.
data.activityDescription: Watch for the interesting creatures that call Bandelier home.
data.longDescription: Bandelier National Monument has a wide variety of mammals, birds, and reptiles with some unique creatures such as Abert's Squirrels. Different animals can be found at different times of the year and in a variety of locations. Remember, always keep your distance from the wildlife (especially the big ones) and try not to cause them to change their behavior. A long lens is recommended for photography.

data.title: Alcove House
data.shortDescription: Learn about the hike and ladder-climb at Bandelier's Alcove House.

images.title: Alcove House
images.caption: Visitors climb ladders to reach Alcove House.

data.seasonDescription: Sometimes closed in winter if ladders are icy.
data.accessibilityInformation: The Alcove House Trail is mostly composed of packed dirt and gravel. There are footbridges to cross that are not ideal for wheelchairs and strollers. The ladders are steep and only recommended for people in good physical shape. It may be extremely difficult for service animals to traverse Alcove House's ladders.
data.ageDescription: Recommended for children (4 years and up) and adults
data.longDescription:
Half way through the Pueblo Loop Trail, a choice must be made; turn back toward the visitor center or continue another half mile each way (1 mile round trip) to Alcove House. Alcove House is located 140 feet above the floor of Frijoles Canyon. The elevated site is now reached by 4 wooden ladders and a number of stone stairs.

CLOSURES
Alcove house may close in the winter due to snow and ice. Occasionally it will close for routine maintenance or resource management work. A sign at the base of the stairs will indicate if Alcove House is closed. Check at the visitor center for details

data.title: Picnicking at Bandelier
data.shortDescription: Bandelier provides multiple options for picnicking and other day-use activities.

images.title: Abert Squirrel
images.caption: Abert Squirrel patrols the Cottonwood Picnic Area.

data.accessibilityInformation: Most picnicking areas at Bandelier are easy to access. The Cottonwood Picnic area and the Parking Lot Island are mostly paved and within walking distance from the Bandelier Visitor Center. Although pets are not allowed on the hiking trails, they are permitted in the picnic areas.
data.petsDescription: Pets are allowed within the picnic areas on a 6-foot leash. Pets are not allowed on trails.
data.longDescription:
Parking Lot Island On the island in the middle of the parking lot this area is shaded and offers several picnic tables, trash cans, and a bear box storage unit.

Cottonwood Picnic AreaCottonwood Picnic Area is located just a short walk across Frijoles Creek from the visitor center in Frijoles Canyon. This area has parking spots with picnic tables. Self- contained stoves are permitted but no open campfires or barbeque grills.

Juniper CampgroundJuniper Campground is open to picnicking until 4:00 PM daily, after that a overnight camping fee will be charged. This area is located on the mesa and can be reached by turning right at the first road past the park entrance station. Picnickers should pick a spot not already occupied by campers. Fires are permitted in the grate provided. Each campground spot has a picnic table, barbeque grill, and a parking space.

data.title: Camping at Bandelier
data.shortDescription: Camping and campground information for Bandelier National Monument.

images.altText: Tall pine trees blanket the Juniper Campground.
images.title: Juniper Campground
images.caption: Tall Ponderosa Pine trees shade the Juniper Campground.

data.accessibilityInformation:
Pets are permitted but must remain on leash at the Juniper and Ponderosa campgrounds. Service animals are allowed in the campgrounds and in most areas of the park. 

Both frontcountry campgrounds have sites designated for visitors with disabilities.
data.petsDescription:
Pets are only allowed in Juniper Campground and Ponderosa Campground, pets are not allowed for Backcountry camping.
All pets must be on a 6-foot leash.
data.longDescription:
There are three different ways to camp in Bandelier. Juniper Campground is our family campground and is intended for small groups of 10 individuals or less. There are two campsites in Juniper Campground designed to handle small groups (10 - 20 people). Ponderosa Campground is a group campground for groups larger than 10 individuals. Backcountry camping is also available with a permit that can be obtained for free at the visitor center. The closest backcountry camping zone is approximately 2 miles from the visitor center.

For more information click on your choice of camping options below.

Ponderosa Group Campground

Juniper Family Campground

Backcountry Camping

data.title: Tyuonyi Overlook Trail
data.shortDescription: Learn about the Tyuonyi Overlook Trail, including roundtrip mileage and where to start the hike.
data.accessibilityInformation: The trail is relatively flat, however, rocky and uneven in some places. It is not wheelchair accessible but is accessible to service animals.
data.longDescription:
See what this trail is like before you hike it. Do a virtual tour here.

The Tyuonyi Overlook Trail begins at Juniper Campground and crosses the mesa to an amazing overlook of Frijoles Canyon and Tyuonyi Pueblo. The 2.2 mile round-trip trail is relatively level but prone to be dusty or muddy depending on the season. This trail is an excellent place to see the common plants of the Pinon-Juniper woodland. The trail passes a number of archeological sites. Please don't climb on the walls or remove artifacts.

data.title: Short Trails
data.shortDescription: Explore Bandelier's scenery and cultural heritage on its many short hiking trails.

images.title: Hiking Under Ponderosa Pines
images.caption: Alcove House trail meanders through tall pine trees.

data.accessibilityInformation: No pets are allowed on park trails, however, service animals are. Some short trails are paved and easy to walk on, while others are on difficult surfaces. These trails may be uneven. rocky, and rugged.
data.longDescription:
Within Bandelier's 33,000 acres there are over 70 miles of trail. Some trails are short easy loops while others can encompass many miles and steep rocky switchbacks. There are even two trails designated for cross-country skiing in the winter.

Pets are not permitted on any park trails.

For more information on short trails, click the links below:
Main (Pueblo) Loop Trail
Alcove House
Tsankawi
Falls Trail
Frey Trail
Frijolito Loop Trail
Tyuonyi Overlook Trail
Burnt Mesa Trail
Cerro Grande Route
Alamo Boundary Trail

data.title: The Frijolito Loop Trail
data.shortDescription: Find out about hiking the Frijolito Loop trail at Bandelier National Monument.

images.altText: Uphill hike along the Frijolito Loop Trail
images.title: The Frijolito Loop Trail
images.caption: Hiking the Frijolito Loop Trail offers spectacular views.

data.accessibilityInformation: The trail is rugged and contains significant elevation gain. This trail is only recommended for people in good physical health. The Frijolito Loop is not wheelchair accessible but is accessible to service animals.
data.longDescription: Frijolito Loop Trail begins in Cottonwood Picnic Area, just across the creek from the visitor center. The trail goes up Frijoles Canyon by using steep switchback path, crosses the mesa passing near an unexcavated archeological site (Frijolito Pueblo) and then drops back into Frijoles Canyon on the Long Trail. Total distance is 2.5 miles. This trail is a difficult climb and can be icy in winter.

data.title: Long Trails
data.shortDescription: Description of Bandelier backcountry and links for longer trails

images.altText: Fall colors in the backcountry of Bandelier
images.title: Upper Frijoles Canyon
images.caption: Autumn colors descend on Upper Frijoles Canyon.

data.seasonDescription: Winter hikes may include snowy or icy trails, while hikes in the summer will be hot and occasionally include thunderstorms.
data.accessibilityInformation: Most backcountry trails are strenuous to hike. Backcountry hikers can expect uneven terrain, elevation gain/loss, climbing, scrambling, and some route-finding. Hiking conditoins and legnths can be difficult for those who are not physically fit or have any physical limitations. Pets are not permitted in the backcountry, however, certified service animals are.
data.longDescription:
Within Bandelier's 33,000 acres there are over 70 miles of trails. Some trails are short easy loops while others are longer and more difficult. Longer backcountry trails often involve hiking more than 12 miles round-trip. Backcountry permits are required and are available at the visitor center for overnight stays in the park's backcountry. Water is not readily available on most backcountry trails. Please check at the visitor center for current conditions before hiking in the backcountry.

Pets, bicycles, and pack animals are not permitted on any park trails.

Frijoles Rim and Canyon Trail
Yapahsi Pueblo
Painted Cave

data.title: Explore the Yapashi Pueblo
data.shortDescription: Description of the Yapashi Pueblo and details about the hike.

images.altText: Cholla Cactus near the Yapashi Pueblo site.
images.title: Cholla Cactus Near the Yapashi Pueblo
images.caption: Cholla Cactus basks in the sun near the unexcavated Yapashi Pueblo site.

data.accessibilityInformation: This trail is considered strenuous and is only recommended for people in good physical shape who are equipped with backcountry knowledge and the ability to navigate in rugged terrain. The Yapashi trail is not wheelchair accessible but is accessible to service animals.
data.longDescription: The hike to Yapashi pueblo is a beautiful, but difficult day hike. It is a 12 mile hike to Yapashi and back. Remember to bring plenty of water, sunscreen, and proper clothing. Yapashi pueblo is an unexcavated pueblo archaeology site.
